filename: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties (1969).pdf
shortTitle: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties
shortSummary: The Vienna Convention codifies the rules for conclusion, interpretation, amendment and termination of treaties between States. In Ecuador v. Mexico, the Convention supplies the legal methodology for interpreting the asylum, diplomatic and anti‑corruption treaties Mexico invokes or is alleged to have breached and for assessing whether Mexico’s acts are compatible with those treaty obligations.
detailedSummary:
Overview and core rules relevant to Ecuador v. Mexico
- Core principles: pacta sunt servanda (Art. 26) and good faith; non‑retroactivity (Art. 28); territorial scope (Art. 29); and the duty not to defeat a treaty’s object and purpose prior to entry into force (Art. 18). These principles frame the starting point that States must perform treaty obligations in good faith and cannot rely on domestic law to avoid them (Art. 27).
- Interpretation rules: the Convention’s general rule of interpretation (Art. 31) requires interpretation in good faith, giving ordinary meaning in context and in light of the treaty’s object and purpose; subsequent agreement and subsequent practice (Art. 31(3)) and preparatory work (Art. 32) are admissible supplementary means. When multiple authentic texts exist, the text best reconciling them with the object and purpose is preferred (Art. 33).
- Treaties and third States: Articles 34–37 govern when treaty provisions create rights or obligations for non‑parties and confirm that, ordinarily, a treaty does not bind third States without their consent (but may create rights for third States if the parties intended that result and the third State assents — Art. 36).
- Successive and conflicting treaties: Article 30 determines which treaty prevails where later and earlier treaties address the same subject matter; Article 41 permits modification of a multilateral treaty between some parties only in narrow circumstances. Article 60 defines consequences of material breach (including possible suspension or termination).
- Dispute procedures and remedies: Part V (Arts. 65–67) prescribes notification procedures and available dispute settlement routes for claims concerning invalidity, termination or other treaty issues, including referral to judicial or conciliation mechanisms under defined conditions.
How the Convention applies to the case at bar (Ecuador v. Mexico)
- Method of treaty interpretation: Ecuador will rely on Art. 31 and 32 to interpret the Caracas Convention (1954), Montevideo Convention (1933), Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations (1961) and the anti‑corruption conventions in the light of their object and purpose (preventing misuse of diplomatic premises, excluding asylum for common crimes, and promoting cooperation against corruption). Ecuador can use the text, the preambles, the parties’ subsequent practice (diplomatic notes, exchanges, OAS resolution) and preparatory materials to show that Mexico’s purported “asylum” for a person convicted of common crimes is incompatible with treaty terms and object and purpose.
- Good faith and “defeating” treaty purposes: Article 18 and Art. 26 support Ecuador’s contention that Mexico may not take acts which defeat the object and purpose of treaties it is bound by (e.g., using diplomatic premises to avoid criminal jurisdiction or to frustrate cooperation obligations under anti‑corruption treaties). Mexico’s press announcements and actions can be characterized as inconsistent with treaty performance in good faith.
- Conflicts among treaties and obligations to third States: Article 30 helps assess interactions among overlapping instruments (e.g., Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations vs. regional asylum conventions vs. anti‑corruption instruments). Articles 34–36 guide claims involving treaty rights or obligations vis‑à‑vis third States (Ecuador may argue the anti‑corruption treaties create obligations to cooperate that are directly applicable between the parties).
- Material breach and consequences: If the Court finds Mexico’s conduct to contravene provisions essential to a treaty’s object and purpose, Article 60 provides the framework for considering suspension, termination or other legal consequences; Ecuador may invoke material breach as legal basis for remedies.
- Procedural path for treaty disputes: Arts. 65–67 provide the procedural sequence for notice and dispute settlement Ecuador can use to show that diplomatic exchanges, failure to cooperate, and subsequent actions gave rise to a treaty dispute properly submitted to the Court.
Practical evidentiary and argument strategies under the Convention
- Rely on Art. 31(1) to argue that ordinary meaning and object/purpose foreclose a broad reading of “asylum” that would include shielding persons convicted of ordinary crimes.
- Use subsequent practice and the parties’ diplomatic notes (Art. 31(3)(b)) — the detailed verbales and press statements — to show that Mexico’s own practice and contemporaneous communications do not support its construction of treaty rights to shelter a convicted national who faces arrest for common crimes.
- Invoke Art. 18 (obligation not to defeat object and purpose) to argue temporary acts (use of embassy premises) that frustrate enforcement of criminal sentences and mutual‑assistance obligations under anti‑corruption instruments are unlawful even if a formal amnesty/asylum declaration is later attempted.
- Apply Art. 30 to reconcile obligations under multiple treaties (showing that the asylum conventions’ clear exclusions for common crimes prevail as between parties that are also bound by Vienna Convention norms on mission functions and inviolability).
- If Mexico claims conflicting treaty rights, use the VCLT rules on third‑state rights (Arts. 34–36) to demonstrate whether anti‑corruption treaties or the Caracas/Montevideo provisions create direct rights/obligations between Ecuador and Mexico and how those should be enforced.
Limitations and cautions
- VCLT governs legal methodology; it does not itself create the substantive prohibitions Ecuador invokes (those come from the specific asylum, diplomatic and anti‑corruption treaties and from customary international law). The Convention is a tool to interpret and apply those instruments and to define remedies for breach.
- Where Mexico argues customary rules or national constitutional protections, Ecuador must show consistency with treaty interpretation (Arts. 27 and 31) and resist domestic‑law defenses (Art. 27).
Conclusion
The Vienna Convention provides the Court with the authoritative interpretive framework and procedural rules Ecuador needs to: (1) read the relevant asylum, diplomatic and anti‑corruption treaties in light of their object and purpose; (2) rely on subsequent practice and communications to demonstrate the ordinary meaning and parties’ common understanding; (3) determine whether Mexico’s conduct amounted to a material breach with legal consequences; and (4) establish that the dispute over treaty application is properly before the Court under the Convention’s dispute procedures.
keyPoints: Article 31 (good‑faith interpretation in context and in light of object and purpose) is central to construing the asylum, diplomatic and anti‑corruption treaties at issue

Article 18 (obligation not to defeat a treaty’s object and purpose) and Article 26 (pacta sunt servanda) support Ecuador’s claim that Mexico must perform treaty obligations in good faith and cannot use diplomatic premises to frustrate enforcement
Articles 34–36 govern when treaty provisions affect third States and are relevant to whether anti‑corruption and asylum rules create direct obligations between Ecuador and Mexico

Article 30 helps resolve conflicts among overlapping treaties (e.g., Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations vs. regional asylum conventions); Article 60 provides the framework for legal consequences of material breach
Articles 65–67 describe the required notification and dispute settlement procedures and support Ecuador’s use of the Court to resolve treaty interpretation and application disputes

filename: Articles on Responsibility of States for Internationally Wrongful Acts (ILC Articles : ARSIWA, 2001).pdf
shortTitle: Responsibility Of States For Internationally Wrongful Acts
shortSummary: The International Law Commission’s ARSIWA (2001) sets the legal framework for state responsibility: when state conduct is attributable and breaches an international obligation, the State incurs responsibility and must cease the act and make reparation. It identifies rules on attribution, breaches, circumstances precluding wrongfulness, and legal consequences (cessation, guarantees of non-repetition, restitution, compensation, and satisfaction).
detailedSummary:
Relevance of ARSIWA to Ecuador v. Mexico and lines of argument Ecuador can deploy under the ILC Articles (ARSIWA):

1. Establishing an internationally wrongful act (Articles 1–3, 12–15)
- Article 2 requires (a) attribution of the conduct to Mexico and (b) a breach of an international obligation. Ecuador can argue that Mexico’s sheltering of Mr. Glas in its embassy, refusal to surrender him and public grant of asylum (with the aim of removing him from Ecuador) satisfy both elements: Mexican conduct is attributable to the State and breaches obligations under the Vienna Convention (Article 41) and the asylum conventions (Montevideo/Caracas) and obligations of non-intervention.
- Article 3 supports Ecuador’s point that domestic characterizations (e.g., Mexico’s internal asylum determinations) cannot negate the international characterization of the acts as wrongful.
- Articles 14–15 address temporal aspects: Ecuador can treat Mexico’s conduct as continuing (presence/refusal from 17 Dec 2023 until removal attempt/related acts), so breach extends for that period.

2. Attribution (Articles 4–11)
- Article 4 covers acts by any State organ. The presence and decisions concerning Mr. Glas involved Mexico’s embassy and notes/press releases by Mexico’s Foreign Ministry and Head of State, which are attributable as acts of State organs.
- Article 7 (excess of authority) means even if embassy staff exceeded instructions, their acts remain attributable. Article 11 (acknowledgement/adoption) covers later official pronouncements adopting the embassy’s conduct.

3. Breach of international obligations (Articles 12; Articles 20–21 for defences)
- Article 12 confirms breach exists when conduct departs from what the obligation requires. Ecuador can show breaches of: (i) Article 41 VCDR obligations (respect local laws, not interfere, not use premises incompatibly); (ii) Montevideo/Caracas asylum rules prohibiting asylum for those prosecuted/convicted for common crimes; (iii) treaty obligations to cooperate on anti-corruption (Inter-American Convention; Merida Convention); and (iv) the non-intervention principle under the UN/OAS Charters (customary law).
- Ecuador should anticipate and rebut potential defenses: ARSIWA Chapter V limits precluding wrongfulness to strict conditions. Mexico could attempt to rely on asylum or necessity/distress — Articles 20–25 show these are narrowly applicable: consent, self-defence, force majeure, distress, necessity all require stringent elements not present here (e.g., necessity requires grave and imminent peril to essential interest and not to have contributed to situation). Article 26 bars invoking circumstances to justify acts contrary to peremptory norms; non-intervention and diplomatic obligations approach jus cogens weight in practice.

4. Consequences and remedies (Part Two: Articles 28–39)
- Article 30 obliges cessation and guarantees of non-repetition — Ecuador can request the Court to order Mexico to cease use of mission to shield nationals and give assurances. Article 31 and 34–37 set reparation modalities: restitution (where feasible), compensation for material/moral injury, and satisfaction (acknowledgment/apology) — Ecuador can seek declarations, assurances, and reparations proportionate to the injury to sovereignty and judicial function. Article 32 prevents Mexico from invoking internal law to excuse non-performance.

5. Invocation, injured State and countermeasures (Part Three: Articles 42–54)
- Article 42 plainly entitles Ecuador as an injured State to invoke Mexico’s responsibility for obligations owed to Ecuador individually (non-interference, respect for laws and jurisdiction). Article 43 requires notice of claim — Ecuador’s diplomatic notes satisfy this prerequisite. If Ecuador contemplates countermeasures, ARSIWA articles 49–53 outline lawful limits: proportionate, non-forcible, respecting human-rights and diplomatic inviolability; Ecuador must show it complied with requirements to call upon Mexico to perform and offer negotiation prior to countermeasures (Article 52).

Practical argument structure for Ecuador at the ICJ:
- Prove attribution: embassy acts and statements by Mexican organs are Mexican State acts (Articles 4,7,11). 
- Prove breach: link those acts to specific treaty and customary obligations (Article 12), emphasizing incompatibility with Article 41 VCDR and the asylum conventions and obligations to cooperate on anti-corruption. 
- Reject defenses: show no lawful circumstance precluding wrongfulness applies (Articles 20–25). 
- Identify remedies: request cessation, assurances of non-repetition (Article 30), and appropriate reparation including satisfaction (Articles 31,34–37). 
- Procedural: confirm Ecuador is an injured State under Article 42 and fulfilled notice requirements of Article 43 (supported by diplomatic notes and exchanges annexed to the Application).
keyPoints: ARSIWA requires attribution plus breach: Mexico’s embassy acts and official pronouncements are attributable state conduct and can be shown to breach VCDR Article 41 and asylum conventions
ARSIWA’s narrow defenses (consent, necessity, distress, force majeure) are unlikely to preclude wrongfulness here; Mexico’s political asylum claim does not meet those strict conditions
Legal consequences under ARSIWA: Ecuador can seek cessation, guarantees of non-repetition, restitution/compensation and satisfaction for injury to its sovereignty and judicial order
ARSIWA Articles 42–44 confirm Ecuador’s standing as an injured State and validate Ecuador’s diplomatic notices and claims prior to invoking the Court’s jurisdiction
If Ecuador contemplates countermeasures ARSIWA limits require proportionality, prior demand/negotiation, and respect for peremptory norms and diplomatic inviolability

filename: Treaty of Peace, Friendship, Commerce, and Navigation (1888).pdf
shortTitle: Treaty Of Peace, Friendship, Commerce, And Navigation
shortSummary: An 1888 treaty on peace, friendship, commerce and navigation reflects 19th‑century state practice on diplomatic relations, treatment of foreigners, and limits on the use of diplomatic premises. In the Ecuador v. Mexico context, it can be offered as historical evidence of customary rules on asylum, non‑intervention, and proper uses of missions.
detailedSummary: The 1888 Treaty Of Peace, Friendship, Commerce, And Navigation (and contemporaneous commercial/diplomatic treaties of the late 19th century) sets out reciprocal obligations between States concerning the treatment and protection of foreign nationals, the privileges and immunities of diplomatic and consular agents, and limitations on special privileges such as asylum or sanctuary. Although phrased in the language of bilateral commerce-and-navigation agreements, these treaties are useful in an ICJ proceeding as evidence of historical State practice and opinio juris bearing on: (a) the scope and limits of inviolability and the legitimate functions of diplomatic premises; (b) the principle that diplomatic privileges do not authorize interference in the receiving State’s domestic criminal enforcement; and (c) obligations to surrender or not shelter persons accused or convicted of ‘common offences’. In Ecuador v. Mexico, Ecuador can rely on the treaty (and similar instruments from the same era) to show that longstanding international practice rejected the use of legations or consular premises to shield persons convicted of ordinary crimes and that States have historically recognized limits on diplomatic asylum. The treaty therefore supports Ecuador’s arguments that Mexico’s sheltering and attempted removal of a national convicted and subject to arrest warrants constituted an improper derogation from Ecuador’s territorial sovereignty and from the proper functions of a mission. Practically, the 1888 instrument would be pleaded not as a directly applicable modern treaty between the Parties but as corroborative historical evidence that informs the content of customary international law and the ordinary meaning of contemporary treaty terms (for example, the Vienna Convention’s Article 41 obligations, and regional asylum conventions invoked by Ecuador). Mexico could counter that earlier treaties sometimes accommodated forms of protection for political refugees and that historical practice is mixed, so the probative weight of a single 1888 treaty is limited; Ecuador should therefore combine it with other regional instruments and later State practice (e.g., Montevideo/Caracas conventions, OAS practice) to demonstrate a continuous rule excluding diplomatic asylum for common crimes and prohibiting misuse of mission premises.
keyPoints: Historical evidence of limits on diplomatic asylum and the idea that legations should not shield persons convicted of ordinary crimes
Supports the proposition that diplomatic premises must be used only for legitimate mission functions and not to obstruct local criminal justice
Can be used to show long‑standing State practice and opinio juris relevant to customary rules on non‑intervention and respect for territorial sovereignty
Probative value is cumulative: most persuasive when combined with regional asylum conventions, Vienna Convention norms, and subsequent State practice
Defendant may challenge its direct relevance; treat as corroborative historical material rather than a binding modern multilateral source between Ecuador and Mexico

filename: Arrest Warrant of 11 April 2000 (Democratic Republic of the Congo v. Belgium).pdf
shortTitle: Arrest Warrant of 11 April 2000 (Democratic Republic Of The Congo v. Belgium)
shortSummary: The ICJ held that issuing and internationally circulating an arrest warrant for an incumbent foreign minister violated that minister’s immunity from criminal jurisdiction and inviolability under customary international law, and ordered Belgium to cancel the warrant and notify authorities to whom it had been circulated. The Court framed its reasoning around the functional purpose of immunities, limits on extraterritorial enforcement of domestic criminal law, and appropriate remedies for state-to-state injury.
detailedSummary: Facts and holding: The case concerned an international arrest warrant issued in Belgium (and circulated through Interpol) for the then-Foreign Minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Mr. Yerodia), charging war crimes and crimes against humanity. The Court found (by majority) that incumbent foreign ministers enjoy full immunity from criminal jurisdiction and inviolability while in office under customary international law, that the mere issue and international circulation of the warrant infringed those immunities and engaged Belgium’s international responsibility, and that Belgium must, by means of its own choosing, cancel the warrant and inform the authorities to whom it had been circulated. Jurisdiction and admissibility objections were rejected. Reasoning: The Court grounded its conclusion on (1) the functional rationale of immunities — protecting the performance of high-ranking officials’ functions and the conduct of international relations — and (2) an examination of treaty materials and state practice showing no established exception to incumbent ministers’ immunities before national courts (even for atrocity crimes) as a matter of customary law. The Court distinguished the question of national courts’ assertion of universal jurisdiction (which it largely avoided deciding in the operative part) from the separate question of immunity, explaining that jurisdictional expansion does not ipso facto negate immunities. Remedies: The Court treated its findings as satisfaction for the moral injury to the Congo but additionally ordered Belgium to cancel the arrest warrant, as the unlawful instrument itself remained extant. Separate and dissenting opinions stressed (variously) the need to address universal jurisdiction (or not), concerns about impunity for international crimes, the evidentiary basis for a customary rule of ministerial immunity, and the practical effect of the remedy ordered. Key jurisprudential points: the decision affirms (i) inviolability and full immunity from foreign criminal process for incumbent foreign ministers as a rule of customary international law, (ii) limits on the extraterritorial effects of domestic criminal measures when they operate against high-ranking foreign officials, (iii) the Court’s willingness to provide remedial relief against a wrongful state act (including ordering cancellation of instruments), and (iv) the Court’s careful distinction between jurisdiction, immunity and remedies while recognizing the normative tension between immunities and accountability for serious international crimes.
keyPoints: Affirmation of customary-law immunity and inviolability for incumbent foreign ministers from foreign criminal jurisdiction, grounded in functional necessity to perform state duties

Issuing and internationally circulating an arrest warrant against an incumbent foreign minister violated the receiving State’s obligation to respect inviolability and engaged international responsibility; Court ordered cancellation of the warrant
Court distinguished the questions of (i) national courts’ jurisdiction (including universal jurisdiction) and (ii) immunity — jurisdictional expansion does not by itself negate immunity

The Court will fashion remedies against unlawful state acts between States (including requiring cancellation/recall of unlawful instruments) even where individual criminal accountability remains a separate issue

The judgment highlights the Court’s methodology: reliance on treaty guidance, state practice and opinio juris, and careful treatment of competing values (immunity vs accountability) — with separate opinions underscoring unresolved tensions and limits of the ruling

filename: Julian Assange : Ecuadorian Embassy (London) matter (diplomatic-asylum : embassy-inviolability issues).pdf
shortSummary: Julian Assange sought and received diplomatic asylum in the Embassy of Ecuador in London (2012–2019), creating a prolonged clash between embassy inviolability under the Vienna Convention and the host State’s obligations to arrest and extradite. The episode exposed legal limits of diplomatic asylum and practical tensions when a receiving State refuses to recognize or facilitate diplomatic asylum.
detailedSummary:
Background: In 2012 Julian Assange entered the Embassy of Ecuador in London to avoid arrest and possible extradition to Sweden and onward to the United States. Ecuador granted him diplomatic asylum and Ecuadorian officials sheltered him inside the embassy. Legal framework: Under the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations (VCDR) embassy premises are inviolable and local police may not enter without the sending State’s consent. Diplomatic asylum (an asylum granted within diplomatic premises) has no universal treaty basis accepted by the UK; recognition of such asylum depends on the receiving State’s consent and relevant regional instruments. Key events and conduct: The UK government insisted on its domestic and treaty obligations to extradite Assange and repeatedly made clear it would arrest him if he left the embassy. The UK threatened—but did not ultimately invoke—the Diplomatic and Consular Premises Act 1987 (which could have withdrawn recognition of the premises and allowed entry). Ecuador refused to surrender Assange, producing a prolonged diplomatic stalemate and heavy political dispute. Legal and practical outcomes: Assange remained inside the embassy for several years; the case demonstrated that diplomatic inviolability can protect an individual physically inside a mission but cannot by itself compel third States to grant safe passage or to recognize diplomatic asylum. It also illustrated that a receiving State may lawfully prioritize its criminal-justice obligations and that the sending State’s use of mission premises for sheltering a convicted or accused local national can create claims of abuse of diplomatic premises and of interference in the receiving State’s internal affairs.

How this matters for Ecuador v Mexico: The Assange episode supplies persuasive factual and legal analogies for Ecuador’s claims that Mexico misused its embassy by sheltering Jorge Glas. Relevant propositions that Ecuador can draw from Assange include: (1) Embassy inviolability protects a person physically inside a mission but does not authorize the sending State to frustrate the receiving State’s lawful criminal-process obligations or to effect extrication without the receiving State’s consent; (2) diplomatic asylum lacks universal binding effect where the receiving State does not accept it, so a sending State’s unilateral grant of asylum cannot trump the receiving State’s arrest warrants; (3) prolonged sheltering of a receiving-State national inside a mission can amount to interference with the receiving State’s sovereignty and may be incompatible with Article 41 VCDR duties not to use mission premises in a manner incompatible with the mission’s functions; and (4) host-State countermeasures (including declaring persona non grata, withdrawing recognition of premises under domestic law, or lawful policing measures taken when inviolability is removed) are recognized instruments for responding to such abuse. These points support Ecuador’s argument that Mexico’s sheltering of Glas and grant of asylum were not a lawful exercise of diplomatic functions but an unlawful interference and misuse of diplomatic premises, undermining claims that Mexico’s conduct was protected by inviolability or asylum doctrines.
keyPoints: Embassy inviolability shelters individuals inside mission premises but does not automatically legalize shielding a local national from lawful arrest or prosecution
Diplomatic asylum lacks universal binding force where the receiving State does not accept it; unilateral grants cannot override the receiving State’s criminal-justice obligations
Using embassy premises to prevent enforcement of domestic criminal judgments can amount to misuse of a mission and interference with the receiving State’s sovereignty under Article 41 VCDR

The Assange case demonstrates practical remedies and responses (persona non grata declarations, domestic statutory measures to withdraw premises recognition, or diplomatic rupture) that a receiving State may employ when mission inviolability is abused

Assange provides persuasive analogy supporting Ecuador’s contention that Mexico’s conduct toward Jorge Glas exceeded lawful diplomatic functions and cannot be justified solely by inviolability or claims of asylum

filename: Nicaragua v. Honduras (1988).pdf
shortTitle: Border and Transborder Armed Actions (Nicaragua v. Honduras)
shortSummary: The ICJ held that it had jurisdiction and that Nicaragua's application was admissible under Article XXXI of the Pact of Bogotá, treating that Article as an autonomous basis for compulsory jurisdiction and examining admissibility obstacles including prior regional procedures. The Court also addressed requirements for conciliation and when an ongoing regional process bars recourse to the Court.
detailedSummary: The Court unanimously found it had jurisdiction under Article XXXI of the Pact of Bogotá and that Nicaragua's application (filed 28 July 1986) was admissible. Key holdings: (1) Article XXXI of the Pact is an autonomous basis for compulsory jurisdiction between Pact parties and is not automatically altered by unilateral declarations accepting (or modifying) the Court's jurisdiction under Article 36 of the Statute; reservations to jurisdiction must be made as reservations to the Pact itself. (2) Article XXXII (conciliation) and Article XXXI are distinct procedures; prior conciliation is not an immutable prerequisite to seisin under XXXI. (3) On admissibility the Court rejected general objections that the application was political or vague, finding that the Application met Statute and Rules requirements. (4) The Court examined whether regional pacific procedures (the Contadora process) barred recourse to the Court under Article IV of the Pact and concluded that the earlier Contadora phase had, by 28 July 1986, come to a standstill (i.e., was effectively concluded), so Article IV did not bar the seisin. The judgment contains extended reasoning on burden of proof, treaty interpretation (travaux and practice), and separate opinions on nuances of Pact interpretation and procedural fairness.
keyPoints: Article XXXI of the Pact of Bogotá is an independent, treaty-based basis for compulsory ICJ jurisdiction between Pact parties and is not superseded by unilateral declarations under Article 36 of the Statute
Conciliation under Article XXXII is not necessarily a prerequisite to judicial seisin under Article XXXI; the two articles are autonomous routes to the Court
An application is admissible even if linked to broader regional/political problems so long as it meets the Statute and Rules requirements and is sufficiently particularized
A prior regional pacific procedure bars Court access only while it is continuing; a process that has come to a standstill is effectively ‘concluded’ for Article IV purposes

filename: Eritrea v. Ethiopia (Partial Award).pdf
shortTitle: Eritrea-Ethiopia Claims Commission - Partial Award: Jus Ad Bellum
shortSummary: The Eritrea‑Ethiopia Claims Commission (Partial Award, Jus ad Bellum) found Eritrea internationally liable for an unlawful resort to force in May 1998 (attack and occupation of Badme and nearby territory) and set principles on when use of force and claims of self‑defence are lawful. The Commission also addressed limits on what factual findings a tribunal may resolve and the distinction between origins of a conflict and legality of the resort to force.
detailedSummary: The Partial Award (Jus ad Bellum) held that: Eritrea’s large‑scale attack on May 12, 1998 against Badme and adjacent areas — territory then peacefully administered by Ethiopia — violated Article 2(4) of the UN Charter and gave rise to Eritrean international responsibility. The Commission rejected arguments that (a) a disputed territorial claim alone authorizes force, and (b) localized border clashes involving small patrols constitute an armed attack permitting self‑defence. It emphasized that self‑defence under Article 51 requires an armed attack of sufficient scale and that States must report measures taken in self‑defence to the Security Council. The Commission also explained it had jurisdiction to decide legality of the use of force even where another instrument contemplated fact‑finding on the origins of the conflict, because the latter did not resolve legal questions of jus ad bellum. Finally, the Commission refused to find that subsequent separate attacks were proven to be part of a single pre‑planned offensive. Relevance to Ecuador v Mexico (ICJ, Model UN): the Award supplies useful legal and methodological propositions Ecuador can invoke. Substantively, it supports the proposition that derogations from a receiving State’s sovereignty require a clear legal basis and cannot be justified by mere unilateral claims (here: Mexico’s asserted “asylum”) — just as the Commission rejected territorial‑dispute as a free‑standing justification for force. Methodologically, it underlines the need to distinguish (and prove) the legal character of State conduct (intervention/non‑intervention) from factual disputes about origins or motives; Ecuador can therefore argue that Mexico’s use of its mission to shield a convicted national constitutes an unlawful derogation from Ecuador’s sovereignty and an unlawful interference since no legal basis (under the Caracas/Montevideo Conventions or other rules) lawfully justified that conduct. The Award’s caution about scale and character of wrongful acts is also helpful for Ecuador to show that even non‑military acts (diplomatic shelter plus public statements) may amount to internationally wrongful interference when they remove a person from the territorial State’s jurisdiction or obstruct judicial processes. Finally, the Commission’s focus on State obligations to bring measures to appropriate international fora (e.g., Security Council in cases of self‑defence) and on the centrality of objective legal criteria can be used to argue that Mexico’s unilateral press‑announcement and failure to follow agreed diplomatic channels aggravated the breach and undermines any claim of lawful asylum or permissible diplomatic function.
keyPoints: Affirms that unilateral derogations from a State’s territorial sovereignty require a clear legal basis; disputed claims do not justify breaking fundamental rules (analogy: misuse of diplomatic premises cannot be justified by asserted asylum)

Establishes that limited or localized incidents do not automatically confer a right of self‑defence — tribunals must assess scale and character of the act (useful to show Mexico’s acts are not lawful exceptions to Ecuador’s sovereignty)

Distinguishes factual origin inquiries from legal adjudication of wrongdoing; emphasizes the need for proof of legal character of State conduct (Ecuador should focus on proving legal elements of intervention and misuse of diplomatic premises)
Reinforces that procedural irregularities (failure to use diplomatic channels, press declarations) and obstructing a receiving State’s law‑enforcement can be relevant indicia of unlawful interference

Demonstrates tribunal practice in attributing international responsibility for violations of core principles (sovereign equality, territorial integrity, non‑intervention) which Ecuador can analogize to Mexico’s sheltering and removal efforts

filename: Gabcikovo-Nagymaros Project (Hungary v. Slovakia, 1997).pdf
shortSummary: The ICJ held that Hungary unlawfully suspended and abandoned parts of the 1977 treaty project, that Czechoslovakia/Slovakia exceeded its rights by putting a unilateral provisional solution into operation, and that the 1977 Treaty remained in force with continuing obligations and compensation consequences. The Court directed the parties to negotiate in good faith, take account of evolving environmental norms, and settle damages and operational arrangements in accordance with the treaty.
detailedSummary: The Court found (1) Hungary was not entitled to suspend and abandon works in 1989 in breach of the 1977 Treaty; (2) Czechoslovakia/Slovakia could prepare alternative measures (Variant C) but was not entitled to put the unilateral diversion into operation in October 1992; (3) Hungary’s 1992 notification of termination did not lawfully terminate the Treaty, which continued to bind Slovakia as successor to Czechoslovakia; and (4) both Parties committed internationally wrongful acts and must negotiate in good faith to restore a joint operational regime, give effect to the treaty’s objectives (including evolving environmental standards), and provide compensation for damage. The Court emphasized: treaty obligations persist despite factual change, unilateral derogations are unlawful unless justified under strict treaty-law grounds (e.g., state of necessity narrowly construed), countermeasures must be proportionate, and newly developed norms (here environmental law) may be taken into account in implementing an existing treaty. It also recommended negotiation, equitable settlement (including the possibility of an overall account/cancellation of claims), and compliance with pacta sunt servanda and good-faith performance.
keyPoints: Unilateral suspension/termination of treaty obligations is not lawful absent narrowly defined legal grounds; treaty continues to bind successor States
A State may take preparatory measures, but putting a unilateral alternative regime into operation can be an internationally wrongful act if it exceeds treaty rights and is disproportionate
States must negotiate in good faith to implement treaty objectives; evolving norms (e.g. environmental law) are relevant to treaty implementation and can be incorporated by agreement
Where both parties commit intersecting wrongful acts, the Court may require compensation but encourage negotiated overall settlements (including offsetting claims)
Countermeasures or unilateral measures must meet strict necessity and proportionality tests; premature or disproportionate unilateral action is condemned and gives rise to responsibility

filename: Convention on Political Asylum (Montevideo, 1933) [Conference of American States].pdf
shortSummary: Regional treaty (Montevideo, 1933) that limits diplomatic/political asylum by prohibiting asylum in legations, warships, military camps or airships for persons accused or convicted of "common offenses" and requiring their surrender to local authorities. It clarifies that the granting State judges the political character of the offence but imposes an obligation to surrender where the offence is common.
detailedSummary: The Convention on Political Asylum (Montevideo, 1933) (hereafter 'Montevideo Convention') (i) replaces the Havana wording on asylum to provide that States shall not grant asylum in legations, warships, military camps or airships to persons accused of or convicted for common offences and that such persons found in those places shall be surrendered as soon as requested by the local government (Article 1); (ii) confirms that the determination whether an offence is political ("judgment of political delinquency") is for the State offering asylum (Article 2); (iii) treats political asylum as humanitarian and non‑reciprocal but recognizes limits where States do not accept asylum (Article 3); and (iv) contains procedural/relationship rules (e.g., replacement of a withdrawn diplomatic agent where asylum causes dispute) and standard ratification/entry into force clauses (Articles 4–9). In relation to the dispute before the Court (Ecuador v. Mexico), the Montevideo Convention is directly relevant because it: (a) expressly bars the grant of asylum in diplomatic premises to persons accused of or convicted of "common offences" and requires surrender upon request by the local government; (b) therefore supports the proposition that Mexico’s sheltering of an Ecuadorian national convicted of corruption in the Mexican embassy in Quito and its announced grant of asylum were unlawful if those offences are correctly characterised as common (non‑political) offences; (c) provides a treaty basis, alongside the Caracas Convention and the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, to argue that a sending State used diplomatic premises in a manner incompatible with the functions of the mission and failed to surrender a person who should have been surrendered; and (d) reinforces Ecuador’s claim of unlawful interference with Ecuador’s criminal jurisdiction and non‑intervention in internal affairs. Practical legal uses in the case at bar: (1) Article 1 furnishes a clear textual obligation to surrender persons accused/convicted of common offences who take refuge in diplomatic premises — Ecuador can invoke this to show Mexico breached an explicit treaty duty; (2) because the Convention addresses asylum in legations specifically, it supports Ecuador’s argument that Mexico’s conduct constituted an abuse of diplomatic premises and incompatible use under Article 41 VCDR; (3) the Convention’s regional character and the fact that both Ecuador and Mexico are historically bound by inter‑American asylum instruments (Montevideo and Caracas) bolster Ecuador’s reliance on regional treaty obligations alongside its claims under anti‑corruption instruments; and (4) while Article 2 vests the decision on political character with the granting State, that allocation does not nullify Article 1’s surrender requirement when offences are common — Ecuador can argue Mexico’s unilateral political characterization cannot override the treaty prohibition where the factual record shows common criminal convictions and ongoing prosecutions. Limitations and considerations: the Montevideo Convention gives the asylum‑granting State the power to judge political character, so Mexico may invoke Article 2 and contest characterization; the treaty is regional and binding only on Parties and insofar as it remains in force between them (so Ecuador must establish Mexico’s obligations under the Convention at the relevant time); and the Convention does not by itself resolve all questions about interplay with the Vienna Convention or customary limits on diplomatic asylum, so Ecuador should deploy it together with the Caracas Convention, VCDR Article 41, and anti‑corruption treaties to show a consistent body of obligations breached by Mexico’s conduct.
keyPoints: Article 1 prohibits granting asylum in legations/warships/military camps/airships to persons accused or convicted of common offences and requires surrender upon request by the local government
Article 2 allocates to the asylum‑granting State the judgment of whether an offence is political, but does not negate Article 1’s surrender duty for common crimes
The Convention is a regional treaty directly relevant to diplomatic asylum and supports Ecuador’s claim that Mexico unlawfully used its embassy to shield a convict from local criminal jurisdiction

In the case at bar the Convention can be used alongside the Caracas Convention and VCDR Article 41 to show treaty‑based obligations breached and to rebut any lawful basis for Mexico’s announced asylum
Limitations: State discretion under Article 2 to characterize offences politically and the need to show both Parties’ treaty obligations remain in force and applicable in the present dispute

shortTitle: Agreement On Extradition Between The United States Of America And The European Union
shortSummary: A multilateral agreement between the United States and the European Union (and its Member States) that standardizes and enhances procedures for extradition cooperation, including definitions of extraditable offences, channels for requests and provisional arrest, transit, temporary surrender and treatment of sensitive information. It supplements and, in specified respects, replaces aspects of existing bilateral extradition treaties between the United States and EU Member States.
detailedSummary: The Agreement on Extradition (signed 25 June 2003; instruments exchanged 2009; entered into force 1 February 2010) establishes common rules and practical mechanisms to facilitate extradition and related cooperation between the United States and EU Member States. Key provisions define extraditable offences by reference to a one‑year custodial threshold (Art. 4); permit streamlined transmission and admissibility of extradition requests and supporting documents without further legalization or authentication where certified by an appropriate authority (Art. 5); allow direct transmission of provisional arrest requests between Ministries of Justice and use of Interpol facilities (Art. 6); authorize transmission of full requests to the requested State’s embassy following provisional arrest to preserve detention time-limits (Art. 7); permit requests for supplementary information to be exchanged directly between Ministries of Justice (Art. 8); provide for temporary surrender for purposes of prosecution with conditions for return and crediting of custody time (Art. 9); set rules for resolving competing requests (Art. 10); enable simplified procedures when the person consents (Art. 11); cover transit and unscheduled landings (Art. 12); address capital punishment concerns (Art. 13); and require consultation and periodic review (Arts. 15, 21). Facilitates rapid operational cooperation: direct provisional arrest requests, use of Interpol, embassy transmission to preserve detention time‑limits, and direct Ministry‑to‑Ministry exchanges for supplementary information (Arts. 5–8)

Provides mechanisms for temporary surrender and transit that permit requested States to balance law‑enforcement interests with protections for detained persons (Arts. 9–12), and safeguards (capital‑punishment conditions, protection of sensitive information) to respect human‑rights and sovereign constraints (Arts. 13–14)

Respects and complements bilateral treaties (Art. 3) and preserves requested States’ non‑derogable domestic grounds for refusal and the need for consultations where constitutional or judicial constraints arise (Art. 17)

filename: Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, 1961 .pdf
shortSummary: The Vienna Convention (1961) codifies the rules governing diplomatic missions, immunities, inviolability of mission premises, and the duties of diplomatic agents and sending States. It balances privileges necessary for mission functions with obligations to respect the laws and sovereignty of the receiving State.
detailedSummary: The Convention establishes key rules directly relevant to Ecuador v. Mexico. Article 22 makes mission premises inviolable and imposes a duty on the receiving State to protect them, while Articles 29–31 and 37 set out personal inviolability and immunities of diplomatic agents and certain staff. Crucially, Article 41(1) imposes duties on persons enjoying privileges and immunities to respect the laws and regulations of the receiving State and not to interfere in its internal affairs; Article 41(3) bars use of mission premises in ways incompatible with the mission's functions. Other provisions (Article 3 on mission functions, Article 9 on persona non grata, Article 27 on official communications, and Articles 45–46 on protection when relations break off) frame the scope and limits of permissible diplomatic activity. In Ecuador v. Mexico, Ecuador relies on Article 41 and related provisions to argue that Mexico misused its mission by sheltering an Ecuadorian national convicted of ordinary crimes, thereby interfering with Ecuador’s administration of justice and violating the duty not to use mission premises incompatibly. The Convention does not create a right to shelter local nationals from criminal process; immunity protects diplomats and certain staff, not private nationals on the receiving State’s territory. Applied to the facts, the Convention supports Ecuador’s contention that prolonged sheltering and a unilateral grant of asylum from mission premises, intended to remove the person from Ecuadorian jurisdiction, exceeded the scope of diplomatic functions and breached Mexico’s obligations under the Convention. The Convention also supplies procedural tools Ecuador may invoke (persona non grata, requests for surrender/cooperation under ordinary channels) and supports arguments about the limits of diplomatic protection when it conflicts with the receiving State’s criminal proceedings.
keyPoints: Article 22 inviolability of mission premises does not permit using those premises to obstruct local criminal justice; the receiving State must also protect against misuse

Article 41(1) expressly requires persons enjoying diplomatic privileges to respect the laws of the receiving State and not to interfere in its internal affairs — central to Ecuador's claim that Mexico's actions were improper
Diplomatic immunities protect accredited agents and specified staff, not private local nationals; sheltering a convicted local national to evade arrest falls outside the Convention's protective scope

Procedural and remedial provisions (Article 9 persona non grata; Articles 45–46 on protection/entrustment when relations break off) offer lawful responses to misuse of a mission and are consistent with Ecuador’s diplomatic steps

The Convention’s balance between privileges and obligations supports Ecuador’s argument that any derogation from another State’s sovereignty (e.g., effective removal of a person from jurisdiction) must have a clear legal basis and cannot be achieved by unilateral misuse of mission premises

filename: Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago Convention).pdf
shortSummary: The Chicago Convention establishes sovereignty of States over their airspace and a framework of rules for international civil aviation, including limits on state aircraft, rights of transit and landing, and obligations to respect domestic aviation laws. While primarily an air-transport instrument, several provisions bear on forcible or unauthorized removal of persons by air and on the use of aircraft in ways that affect a receiving State’s sovereignty and public order.
detailedSummary: Overview: The Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago Convention) recognizes each State’s complete and exclusive sovereignty over the airspace above its territory (Art. 1) and establishes rules governing civil and state aircraft, rights of transit, landing, and the applicability of domestic aviation laws to foreign aircraft. Key provisions relevant to Ecuador v. Mexico: - Article 1 (Sovereignty): affirms that a State controls its airspace — any use of air transport to remove persons from a State’s territory without that State’s consent implicates sovereign control over entry and exit by air. - Article 3 (Civil and state aircraft): distinguishes civil from state aircraft and provides that state aircraft shall not fly over or land in the territory of another State without authorization or special agreement (Art. 3(c)); States must issue regulations for state aircraft with due regard for civil navigation (Art. 3(d)). - Article 4 (Misuse of civil aviation): contracting States agree not to use civil aviation for any purpose inconsistent with the aims of the Convention — this supports objections to using civil aircraft to effect an unauthorized extraction that interferes with the receiving State’s legal process. - Article 5–7, 10, 11 (Flights, scheduled services and landing/cabotage): set out rights and limits for non‑scheduled and scheduled flights, and require entry/exit and customs/immigration formalities at designated airports — forcible or clandestine removal by air would be inconsistent with these rules if conducted without Ecuador’s authorization. - Article 16 (Search of aircraft) and Articles 22–24 (facilitation, customs/immigration): underline the receiving State’s authority over immigration, customs and inspection on entry/exit by air. Relevance to the case at bar (Ecuador v. Mexico): - For Ecuador’s claim: The Convention can be used to reinforce Ecuador’s argument that any deliberate plan by Mexico to remove Mr. Glas from Ecuador by air without Ecuador’s consent would violate Ecuador’s sovereignty over its airspace (Art. 1), its domestic aviation and immigration regime (Arts. 10, 11, 22–24), and the Convention’s prohibition on misuse of aviation (Art. 4). If Mexico intended to use state aircraft (or civil aircraft under Mexican control) to depart Ecuador without authorization, Article 3(c) is directly engaged because state aircraft require authorization to fly over/land in another State. - For Mexico’s possible response / limitations: The Convention primarily regulates air navigation and aircraft; it does not govern diplomatic asylum or the use of diplomatic premises. Mexico could argue the Convention is only marginally relevant to actions that took place entirely within the receiving State’s territory (i.e., shelter in an embassy) unless there was a concrete attempt to use aircraft to extract Mr. Glas. Mexico can also invoke Art. 3(c) to argue that any outbound Mexican state aircraft would require Ecuador’s authorization, underscoring that the Convention supports, rather than contradicts, the requirement of consent for removal by air. Practical evidentiary uses in proceedings: - If Ecuador adduces evidence that Mexico planned or attempted to move Mr. Glas by air (press statements promising safe conduct and removal), the Court can rely on the Convention to show such removal would have required Ecuador’s authorization and thus constituted an infringement of sovereignty and aviation rules. - If Mexico used or intended to use a state aircraft, Ecuador can cite Article 3(c) to show that such a flight would be unlawful without prior authorization. - The Convention can be deployed alongside diplomatic and asylum treaties (Vienna Convention, Caracas/Montevideo Conventions) to demonstrate the broader legal landscape protecting Ecuador’s territorial jurisdiction and the illegitimacy of extrajudicial extraction by air. Limits: The Chicago Convention does not address embassy immunity, asylum law in diplomatic missions, or the lawfulness of sheltering a person inside diplomatic premises; it therefore cannot by itself prove misuse of diplomatic premises but is a strong supplementary instrument where air transport or attempted evacuation by air is alleged.
keyPoints: Affirms State sovereignty over airspace (Art. 1) — unauthorized removal by air implicates sovereignty and entry/exit controls
Distinguishes state and civil aircraft; state aircraft require authorization to enter/land in another State (Art. 3(c))
Prohibits misuse of civil aviation for purposes inconsistent with Convention aims (Art. 4) — supports objections to unauthorized extrication by air
Requires compliance with national laws on admission, clearance, immigration and customs for aircraft entering territory (Arts. 10–13, 22–24)

Works as a complementary legal basis to show that any planned or attempted air removal of Mr. Glas by Mexico would have required Ecuador’s consent and thus could constitute a violation of Ecuador’s sovereignty

shortTitle: Charter Of The Organization Of American States
shortSummary: The OAS Charter establishes principles and organs for inter‑American cooperation, including respect for sovereign equality, non‑intervention, peaceful settlement of disputes, and promotion of representative democracy. In Ecuador v. Mexico these provisions support Ecuador’s claims that Mexico unlawfully interfered in Ecuador’s internal affairs and violated obligations to respect Ecuador’s sovereignty and legal order.
detailedSummary: The Charter of the Organization of American States (OAS) sets out core principles binding on Member States: sovereign equality, non‑intervention, territorial integrity, respect for international law and treaties, and promotion and consolidation of representative democracy (Articles 1–3, 10, 18–19). It also creates procedures and organs for peaceful settlement of disputes (Articles 24–29, Chapter IX–XIII) and affirms that Member States must abstain from interventions in the internal affairs of others (Article 3(e); Article 19). Relevant functions and competencies of the Permanent Council and General Assembly include assisting in peaceful settlement, recommending procedures, and taking measures to restore or protect friendly relations (Articles 80–91). In Ecuador v. Mexico, the Charter can be invoked to show that: (1) Mexico’s sheltering of a convicted Ecuadorian national inside its embassy and the grant of diplomatic/political asylum that would remove him from Ecuador’s jurisdiction amounts to interference in Ecuador’s internal affairs and a derogation from Ecuador’s sovereignty; (2) such conduct contravenes the duty of Member States to respect the laws and jurisdiction of other States and to abstain from intervening (Articles 3, 10, 19); and (3) Ecuador is entitled to seek peaceful settlement and cooperative remedies through OAS organs and, where appropriate, judicial settlement, because the Charter expressly contemplates settlement mechanisms for disputes between Member States (Articles 24–27, 80–91). The Charter also supports Ecuador’s contention that regional instruments and collective obligations (including cooperation to preserve democratic processes and the rule of law) impose duties not to take actions that disrupt another State’s domestic legal processes. While the Charter does not itself prescribe remedies before the International Court of Justice, its principles and procedural framework bolster Ecuador’s arguments on state responsibility, non‑intervention, and the obligation to respect the territorial State’s judicial processes, and they provide a regional context that the Court may consider when assessing breaches of obligations owed between OAS Member States.
keyPoints: Articles 1–3 and 10–19 affirm sovereign equality, territorial integrity, and a strict prohibition on intervention in the internal affairs of other Member States, directly supporting Ecuador’s non‑intervention claims.

Articles 24–29 and Chapters IX–XIII provide for peaceful settlement mechanisms and empower OAS organs (Permanent Council, General Assembly) to assist disputes — supporting Ecuador’s right to seek regional and judicial remedies.

The Charter’s emphasis on representative democracy and respect for legal processes (Articles 2(b), 3(d), 45) reinforces Ecuador’s claim that obstruction of its judicial system undermines obligations among Member States.

Provisions on duties of States to respect one another’s rights and laws (Articles 11, 13, 19) can be cited to show Mexico’s embassy conduct and asylum decision derogated from Ecuador’s jurisdiction and legal order.

Although not a source of ICJ jurisdiction, the Charter supplies regional norms and expectations that the Court may consider when evaluating whether Mexico breached obligations of non‑interference and cooperation with Ecuador.

filename: Convention Against Torture.pdf
shortSummary: The Convention Against Torture (CAT) establishes State obligations to prevent torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, criminalize and prosecute such acts, provide remedies and ensure non-refoulement where there are substantial grounds to believe a person would face torture. Relevant provisions include obligations to prevent torture (Arts. 2, 10–13), non-refoulement (Art. 3), criminalisation and jurisdiction (Arts. 4–7), mutual assistance and extradition (Arts. 8–9), and prompt investigation and remedy (Arts. 12–14).
detailedSummary:
Overview: The CAT binds States Parties to a comprehensive regime: prohibit and criminalize torture (Art. 1, Art. 4); adopt domestic measures to prevent torture (Art. 2); refuse transfer (expulsion, return, extradition) when there are substantial grounds for believing the person would be in danger of torture (Art. 3); investigate and provide remedies for allegations of torture (Arts. 12–14); and cooperate in criminal matters and mutual legal assistance (Arts. 8–9). The Convention also creates reporting and monitoring mechanisms (Committee against Torture, Part II).

Relevant provisions for Ecuador v. Mexico and how they could be invoked:
- Article 3 (non‑refoulement): Mexico could potentially rely on Art. 3 to justify not surrendering or removing an individual from its mission/territory if it legitimately believed Glas faced a real risk of torture upon return to Ecuador. The provision requires a State to consider all relevant information (including patterns of systematic violations) before transferring a person. Ecuador can counter that no such risk exists: the facts show criminal convictions and ongoing prosecutions in ordinary courts, and Ecuador can present evidence that Glas would not face torture or ill‑treatment, undermining any Art. 3 claim by Mexico.

- Articles 2, 10–13 (prevention, training, investigation): Ecuador can argue Mexico breached its positive obligations under CAT by using diplomatic premises in a way that frustrated Ecuadorian investigations and enforcement of criminal sentences, and by failing to take measures (e.g., not coordinating cooperative investigative or custodial steps) to prevent possible ill‑treatment in the broader regional context. Conversely, Mexico could argue its actions were aimed at protecting an individual from ill‑treatment and that it complied with training and prevention obligations; Ecuador would need to show no substantive prevention rationale existed.

- Articles 4–9 (criminalization, jurisdiction, custody, extradition, mutual assistance): Ecuador may rely on Arts. 8–9 to assert that Mexico failed to afford “the greatest measure of assistance” in corruption‑related criminal proceedings and improperly obstructed Ecuador’s jurisdiction by shielding Glas. If Mexico invoked CAT to refuse extradition or surrender, Ecuador can argue that CAT does not authorize harbouring persons convicted of ordinary crimes absent a demonstrable risk of torture, and that the asylum/conduct at issue cannot displace mutual‑assistance obligations in criminal matters where no torture risk exists. Additionally, Art. 6 (custody and preliminary inquiry) contemplates that a State where an alleged offender is present should take custody and inform other relevant States and make a prompt inquiry — Ecuador can argue Mexico violated those procedural duties by failing to take custody in a manner that enabled Ecuadorian proceedings.

- Articles 12–14 (investigation, complaint, redress): Ecuador can point to the CAT duty to promptly and impartially investigate reasonable grounds for ill‑treatment; Mexico’s conduct could be framed as impeding Ecuador’s own investigatory and remedial processes. If Mexico asserts protection obligations under CAT, Ecuador can demand that Mexico produce evidence of any credible allegations of torture risk and of steps Mexico took (investigations, diplomatic assurances, monitoring) to discharge CAT duties.

Practical lines of argument for the Court (ways the Convention can be used by each Party):
- Ecuador’s use of CAT: show there was no real risk of torture (Art. 3) to negate any lawful basis for Mexico’s refusal to surrender; emphasise Mexico’s failure to observe Art. 6 procedures (custody, notification, inquiry) and Arts. 8–9 mutual‑assistance duties in criminal matters; invoke Arts. 2 and 12–13 to allege Mexico’s conduct frustrated prevention, investigation and cooperation obligations under CAT.
- Mexico’s potential use of CAT: if it raises CAT defensively, Mexico must identify specific, credible grounds to believe Glas faced torture if returned (Art. 3), and show it took proportionate and compatible measures (e.g., offering asylum, seeking assurances, initiating inquiries) — otherwise the Court will likely find the CAT does not justify using diplomatic premises to prevent Ecuadorian enforcement of lawful sentences.

Net effect for the Court: CAT is principally about protecting individuals from torture and obliges States to refuse transfers when a real risk exists; it does not authorise unilateral derogations from the territorial State’s criminal jurisdiction or the misuse of diplomatic premises to shield convicted persons in the absence of a demonstrated torture risk. The Convention therefore supplies both a potential justification (for Mexico if genuine risk is shown) and a strong rebuttal (for Ecuador if Mexico cannot substantiate a risk and has obstructed judicial cooperation and custody procedures).
keyPoints: Article 3 (non‑refoulement) is central: it permits refusal of transfer only where substantial grounds exist to believe the person would face torture — Mexico must prove such grounds to justify non‑surrender.

Procedural duties (Art. 6) and mutual assistance/extradition provisions (Arts. 8–9) support Ecuador’s claim that Mexico should have cooperated and not obstructed enforcement of domestic criminal judgments.

Prevention, investigation and remedy obligations (Arts. 2, 12–14) cut two ways: they require States to prevent and investigate torture but do not permit unilateral refuge that undermines another State’s jurisdiction absent a real risk.

If Mexico invokes CAT defensively, the Court will assess objective evidence of risk, consultation/assurances offered, and whether Mexico followed CAT’s procedural obligations before denying surrender.

Overall, CAT does not provide a blanket justification for using diplomatic premises to shield a convicted national; it requires concrete, credible evidence of torture risk and fulfilment of procedural and cooperative duties.

filename: Lopez Burgos v. Uruguay (Human Rights Committee, 1981).pdf
shortSummary: The Human Rights Committee found that Uruguay violated the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights by abducting, detaining and subjecting Lopez Burgos to inhuman treatment and by failing to investigate; the Committee also addressed the reach of a State's obligations to persons outside its territory. The decision highlights State responsibility for acts of agents abroad and the duty to investigate and remedy rights violations.
detailedSummary: Facts and findings: Lopez Burgos, a trade-union activist who had fled Uruguay to Argentina, was alleged to have been abducted by Uruguayan military personnel (with alleged assistance from Argentine actors), detained in Argentina and secretly returned to Uruguay, where he was held incommunicado and tortured. The Human Rights Committee (HRC) examined submissions including detailed allegations and witness testimony provided by the victim's wife. Uruguay did not rebut the facts or show that it had investigated. The HRC concluded that Uruguay breached Covenant obligations—notably Article 7 (prohibition of torture) and Article 2(1) (the duty to respect and ensure rights to everyone within a State’s territory)—and criticized Uruguay’s failure to investigate the allegations and provide an effective remedy. The Committee also commented on the extraterritorial dimension of State responsibilities where conduct by State agents produced effects beyond the State’s borders. Relevance and legal principles: Lopez Burgos establishes (i) that a State can be held internationally responsible for rights violations committed by its agents even when the facts involve cross-border conduct; (ii) that a State’s failure to investigate credible allegations and to provide remedies aggravates its responsibility; and (iii) that human-rights obligations may apply to persons affected by a State’s actions outside its territory where those actions are attributable to the State and affect protected rights.
keyPoints: State responsibility for violations committed by its agents abroad and for effects produced outside its territory where conduct is attributable to the State
Obligation to investigate credible allegations of torture and ill-treatment and to provide effective remedies; failure to do so constitutes a further breach
Prohibition of torture (Article 7 ICCPR) is absolute and state denials or silence are insufficient in the face of substantiated allegations
The decision is persuasive authority showing human-rights obligations can inform and constrain diplomatic and extraterritorial conduct

filename: United Nations Convention Against Corruption (Mérida Convention).pdf
shortSummary: The United Nations Convention against Corruption (Merida Convention) establishes comprehensive standards for prevention, criminalization, international cooperation, and asset recovery to combat corruption. Its provisions require States Parties to cooperate widely in investigations, mutual legal assistance, extradition and the return of proceeds of corruption.
detailedSummary: Overview and relevant provisions: The Convention (adopted 2003 at Merida) sets out preventative obligations (Chapter II), criminalization standards (Chapter III), broad mutual legal assistance and extradition rules (Articles 43–46, 55–56), law‑enforcement cooperation (Articles 48–50), and a strong asset‑recovery regime (Articles 51–59, especially Articles 52–55 and 57). Key criminalization articles include bribery (Arts.15–16), embezzlement (Art.17), laundering (Art.23) and related offences; Article 31 requires States to enable freezing, seizure and confiscation of proceeds of offences. The Convention also calls for specialized anti‑corruption and law‑enforcement bodies (Arts.6, 36), protections for witnesses and reporting persons (Arts.32–33), and preventive measures such as enhanced scrutiny of financial accounts for politically exposed persons (Art.52). Mutual legal assistance (Art.46) is to be afforded “to the widest measure” and States must not decline assistance on grounds such as bank secrecy (Art.46(8)). The Convention affirms that asset return is a fundamental principle (Art.51) and provides procedures for identifying, freezing, confiscating and returning proceeds (Arts.54–57).Application to Ecuador v. Mexico and lines of argument: Ecuador can rely on the Merida Convention to show that Mexico owed specific, treaty‑based obligations to cooperate in criminal matters concerning corruption and the recovery/prevention of flight of proceeds and suspects. Relevant arguments Ecuador can press before the Court include: (1) Mexico breached its duty of cooperation under Articles 43 and 46 by sheltering an individual convicted of corruption in Ecuador and refusing to accede to lawful requests for surrender or for police access to embassy premises; (2) Mexico’s actions frustrated Ecuador’s ability to secure evidence, effect arrest and prevent transfer of a person who was subject to outstanding criminal process for offences covered by the Convention (embezzlement, bribery, illicit association), contrary to Articles 23, 31 and 52–55 which require States to identify, freeze and assist in recovery of proceeds and to facilitate extradition/mutual legal assistance; (3) Mexico’s purported grant of diplomatic asylum and use of mission premises to remove a convicted national undermines the Convention’s preventive obligations (Arts.5–14, Art.52 regarding enhanced scrutiny for politically exposed persons) because it obstructed law enforcement steps designed to prevent dissipation or transfer of proceeds and to enforce criminal sentences; (4) by denying assistance and failing to cooperate, Mexico frustrated the Convention’s core asset‑recovery objective (Art.51 and Arts.54–57), including Ecuador’s right to request tracing, freezing and confiscation of assets and to obtain the individual for prosecution or enforcement of sentence; (5) the Convention’s prohibition on using bank secrecy or other domestic rules to bar cooperation (Art.46(8), Art.31(7)) supports Ecuador’s position that Mexico cannot rely on internal or procedural pretexts to refuse requests. Practical litigation uses: Ecuador may cite specific treaty provisions (Arts.43–46, 48, 51–55, 31, 52) to show an international legal obligation breached by Mexico’s conduct, and to rebut any argument that asylum/diplomatic functions justify refusal to cooperate in corruption matters. Ecuador can also use the Convention to request measures preserving evidence, facilitating return or freezing of assets, and to characterize Mexico’s conduct as inconsistent with its international obligations to prevent impunity for corruption and to cooperate in asset recovery.
keyPoints: Merida Convention (UN Convention against Corruption) creates binding obligations of prevention, criminalization and wide mutual legal assistance between States Parties

Articles 43–46 and 48 require the widest measure of cooperation in investigations, mutual legal assistance and extradition for corruption offences and prohibit refusal of assistance on grounds such as bank secrecy

Articles 51–57 make asset recovery a fundamental principle and require States to identify, freeze, seize and return proceeds of corruption, supporting Ecuador’s claims that Mexico unlawfully impeded enforcement and possible recovery

Article 31 (freezing/seizure/confiscation) and Article 52 (enhanced scrutiny of politically exposed persons) support interim preservation measures and show State obligations to prevent transfer or dissipation of corrupt proceeds

Ecuador can argue that Mexico’s sheltering and removal of a convicted national frustrated treaty duties under the Merida Convention and cannot be justified by diplomatic or asylum claims when offences are ordinary corruption crimes

filename: Charter of the United Nations.pdf
shortSummary: The UN Charter establishes fundamental principles of sovereign equality, non‑intervention, peaceful settlement of disputes, and the role of the International Court of Justice. These principles are directly relevant to Ecuador’s claims that Mexico interfered in its internal affairs and breached obligations under international law in the Glas Espinel matter.
detailedSummary:
The Charter sets out core obligations and principles that frame State conduct between members and before the ICJ. Key provisions for this case include Article 1 (purposes: maintain international peace and security, promote respect for obligations arising from treaties and international law), Article 2 (in particular sovereign equality of States, obligation to fulfil Charter duties in good faith, duty to settle disputes by peaceful means, and the corollary non‑intervention principle), Chapter VI (encouraging peaceful settlement of disputes by negotiation or judicial means), Chapter XIV (confirming the International Court of Justice as the UN’s principal judicial organ and Articles 92–94 requiring compliance with Court decisions), and Articles 56 and 103 (cooperation with the Organization and Charter primacy over conflicting treaty obligations).

Applied to Ecuador v. Mexico, the Charter supports Ecuador’s argument that: (1) States must respect each other’s sovereignty and refrain from interference in internal affairs; Mexico’s sheltering and attempted removal of an Ecuadorian national convicted and subject to arrest can be framed as an unlawful derogation from Ecuador’s territorial jurisdiction and an intervention contrary to the Charter’s non‑intervention principle and the Friendly Relations Declaration as an interpretive source; (2) disputes between Member States that involve questions of international law or alleged breaches of international obligations are properly addressed by peaceful settlement means including judicial settlement before the ICJ (Articles 1, 2 and Chapter VI); Ecuador may therefore rely on the Charter both substantively and procedurally to justify seisin of the Court and relief; (3) the ICJ’s role and the obligation of Members to comply with its decisions (Articles 92–94) underpin Ecuador’s request that legal consequences be declared and reparations ordered; and (4) where treaty obligations and Charter principles align (e.g., non‑intervention, respect for territorial jurisdiction, cooperation in law enforcement), the Charter’s primacy (Article 103) strengthens Ecuador’s case that Mexico could not lawfully invoke regional asylum instruments or diplomatic privileges to override Ecuador’s territorial sovereignty and criminal process.

In arguing before the ICJ, Ecuador can therefore use the Charter to: frame Mexico’s conduct as an unlawful interference with Ecuador’s sovereignty and judicial functions; place the dispute squarely within the Court’s judicial remit and stress the duty of States to resolve such disputes peacefully (including by litigation before the ICJ); and invoke the Court’s authority and States’ Charter obligations to seek binding relief and the legal consequences of Mexico’s internationally wrongful acts.
keyPoints: Charter Principles: Sovereign equality and non‑intervention (Article 2) support Ecuador’s claim that Mexico unlawfully interfered in its internal affairs by sheltering and seeking to remove a convicted national.

Peaceful Settlement & ICJ Role: The Charter encourages peaceful dispute settlement and recognizes the ICJ as the principal judicial organ (Chapter VI and Article 92), reinforcing Ecuador’s choice to bring the dispute to the Court.

Obligation To Comply: Articles 94–95 impose an obligation to comply with ICJ decisions and permit recourse to the Security Council if a State fails to perform its judgment, bolstering requests for binding remedies.

Primacy & Cooperation: Article 103 (Charter primacy) and Articles 55–56 on cooperation support Ecuador’s argument that Charter norms prevail over conflicting treaty or unilateral acts and that States must cooperate in upholding rule‑of‑law obligations.

Procedural & Substantive Support: The Charter both procedurally validates ICJ jurisdiction for interstate disputes over international law and substantively supplies general principles (non‑intervention, respect for territorial jurisdiction) to frame Mexico’s conduct as internationally wrongful.

filename: American Treaty on Pacific Settlement (Pact of Bogotá, 1948) [Conference of American States].pdf
shortTitle: American Treaty On Pacific Settlement (Pact Of Bogotá)
shortSummary: The Pact of Bogotá (1948) obliges American states to settle inter-state disputes by peaceful regional procedures and recognizes the ICJ’s compulsory jurisdiction for juridical disputes among American states. It sets out a hierarchy of peaceful means (negotiation, good offices, mediation, conciliation, arbitration, judicial settlement) and procedural rules for their application.
detailedSummary: The Pact of Bogotá requires High Contracting Parties to use pacific procedures to resolve controversies and, where appropriate, accepts the International Court of Justice’s compulsory jurisdiction for juridical disputes between American states (Article XXXI). Relevant provisions include the obligation to attempt regional procedures first (Articles II–IV), the referral of preliminary questions of domestic jurisdiction to the ICJ (Article V), the requirement to refrain from measures that interfere with ongoing peaceful procedures (Article XVI), and the rules on recourse to the ICJ or arbitration if conciliation fails (Articles XXXII–XXXVI). In Ecuador v. Mexico, Ecuador relies on the Pact both as a basis for the Court’s compulsory jurisdiction and as a framework that emphasizes peaceful regional settlement and respect for domestic jurisdiction. The Pact supports Ecuador’s procedural position that a legal dispute exists between two American States and that the ICJ may be seised for legal questions concerning interpretation of treaties, questions of international law, the existence of facts constituting breaches of international obligations, and reparation (Article XXXI). The Pact’s provisions on the primacy of peaceful procedures and the Court’s role in deciding jurisdictional preliminaries (Article V and Article XXXIII) strengthen Ecuador’s contention that the dispute is justiciable. Moreover, the Pact’s insistence that parties refrain from acts that might hinder conciliation (Article XVI) and its rules on obligations not to resort to diplomatic protection to circumvent domestic remedies (Article VII) can be invoked to argue that Mexico’s use of diplomatic premises and its asylum claim improperly interfered with Ecuador’s domestic judicial processes and regional legal framework. Finally, the Pact’s binding recognition of ICJ jurisdiction for juridical disputes lends procedural force to Ecuador’s application and constrains arguments by Mexico that the matter is non-justiciable or exclusively domestic.
keyPoints: Article XXXI provides compulsory ICJ jurisdiction for juridical disputes among American States, supporting Ecuador’s seisin of the Court.
Article V and XXXIII allow the Court to decide preliminary questions of domestic jurisdiction, enabling adjudication on whether Mexico’s acts are justiciable international wrongs.
